docs.snippet: ROSENBERG--Fred L., died peacefully a month shy of his 96th birthday while independently living in his new home amid new friends at Kendal on Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 23, 2014. Fred passed ten years to the day after the death of his...
docs.lead_paragraph:
ROSENBERG--Fred L.,

died peacefully a month shy of his 96th birthday while independently living in his new home amid new friends at Kendal on Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 23, 2014. Fred passed ten years to the day after the death of his beloved wife of 56 years, artist Joan Mattison Rosenberg, who never left his thoughts. Navy Lieutenant on LST 281 in a D-Day Landing, and later captain of LST 357 in the Pacific, Fred went on to success as textile marketing executive for leading knit firms including Fab Industries, creating many iconic fabrics such as "Supersuede." An avid sportsman, he played outfield for Syracuse University in the Class of 1939, semi- pro baseball in Boston, and into his 90s helped coach and took batting practice with The Kettle softball team in a Central Park league. Published playwright, poet, composer, and spirited performer for friends and family, Fred was a favorite piano pupil of Paul Creston, crooned with an orchestra in college, and was a lifelong student of music, literature and art. Warm, loving and spiritual, Fred is survived by his close sister Janet Black of Pocasset, MA, his dear daughter Vicki Rosenberg, his admiring son Eric and daughter-in-law Helen, and his devoted grandchildren Karen Rosenberg, Stuart M. Rosenberg, and Stuart's wife Halsey Varady. Memorial Service Sunday, January 25, 2015 at 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Contributions in Fred's memory may be made to The Art Students League of New York, attn: Joan M. Rosenberg Memorial Scholarship Fund, 215 West 57th St., NYC, NY 10019.

docs.snippet: Syrian fighters and activists who once gathered in southern Turkey to plan a revolution are now marooned, their hopes rapidly deflating....
docs.lead_paragraph: Syrian fighters and activists who once gathered in southern Turkey to plan a revolution are now marooned, their hopes rapidly deflating.
docs.abstract: Antakya Journal; Turkish city of Antakya, which is on border with Syria, experienced boom in early days of Syrian conflict when foreign fighters and activists used it as way station in their journey to join insurgents fighting government of Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad; many of young men who joined insurgency have returned to Antakya, where they live a marooned existence, their hopes for future dashed with failure of revolution.

headline.main: Vanguard of Syria’s Uprising, Now on the Run From ISIS, Weighs a Bleak Future
headline.print_headline: Vanguard of Syrian Uprising, Now on the Run, Weighs a Bleak Future

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

docs.snippet: In a time when couples overshare, we could use some cautionary tales about all that they miss....
docs.lead_paragraph: In a time when couples overshare, we could use some cautionary tales about all that they miss.
docs.abstract: Ben Dolnick Riff essay laments that television shows like The Affair and movies like Gone Girl fail in their promise to expose ways couples in relationships remain utterly alien to one another; recommends Evan S Connell novels Mrs Bridge and Mr Bridge, which shows how distant even a people in a loving marriage can be from one another.

docs.snippet: The feminist mantra that never was....
docs.lead_paragraph: The feminist mantra that never was.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Szalai First column reflects on fact that phrase 'having it all,' popularized by Helen Gurley Brown book Having It All: Love, Success, Sex, Money ... Even if You're Starting With Nothing, has become timeworn; notes Brown herself disliked the title of the book and argued with her editors about it; laments that use of phrase to describe goals of women's right movement has trivialized actual issues movement was trying to address.

headline.main: The Complicated Origins of ‘Having It All’
